metadata./Title: Successful administration of cetuximab using dose escalation method: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Introduction:
Introduction Cetuximab, used to treat head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and metastatic colorectal cancer, 
can cause severe infusion reactions.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report an 87-year-old East Asian woman with stage IV ileocecal signet ring cell carcinoma 
who experienced severe allergic reactions to cetuximab despite pre-treatment. A dose escalation method, involving weekly incremental doses with comprehensive pre-treatment and close monitoring, was employed, successfully 
reducing allergic reactions and allowing safe administration.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This approach demonstrates a viable alternative for patients with hypersensitivity to cetuximab, warrant ing further research for personalized treatment optimization.
Keywords  Cetuximab, Desensitization, Dose escalation, Infusion reaction, Hypersensitivity, Case report
Introduction
Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody primarily used to 
treat squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck can cer and RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer [1, 2]. 
As a targeted therapy, cetuximab works by binding to the 
epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), inhibiting the 
growth and spread of cancer cells [3]. However, infusion 
reactions to cetuximab have become a significant issue in 
clinical practice, limiting its use [4]. These reactions often 
present as allergic responses, including rash, itching, and 
difficulty breathing, and can even lead to anaphylactic 
shock [ 5, 6]. Such reactions not only affect the patient’s 
treatment experience, but can also lead to treatment 
interruption, thereby impacting efficacy [7].Case presentation
The patient is an 87-year-old East Asian woman with a 
history of primary hypertension, without a previous his tory of atopy or drug allergy, and no family history of 
cancer. She presented with recurrent abdominal pain 
and bloody stools 2 years ago. A computed tomography 
(CT) scan suggested thickening of the ileocecal wall and 
partial bowel obstruction. On 7 August 2022, she under went laparoscopic exploration, which revealed a tumor 
in the ileocecal region, with peritoneal, right diaphragm, 
and bladder–vaginal interface implants. Palliative right 
hemicolectomy and peritoneal nodule resection were 
performed. Postoperative pathology confirmed signet 
ring cell carcinoma pT4bN2M1. Genetic testing showed 
MSI-H, BRAF p.V600E mutation, TMB 40.84muts/Mb, 
and PD-L1 TPS < 1% and CPS < 1.
Due to her advanced age and diagnosis of stage IV 
ileocecal signet ring cell carcinoma with MSI-H, singleagent immunotherapy was recommended. She began 
her first cycle of pembrolizumab on 6 September 2022, 
and completed 12 cycles by 12 March 2024, with the best 
response being partial remission (PR). During treatment, 
she experienced immune-related thyroiditis, secondary Open Access

symptomatic treatments.
In March 2024, the patient experienced disease pro gression with vaginal bleeding, managed with palliative 
radiotherapy. Systemic therapy was switched from pem brolizumab to cetuximab combined with vemurafenib. 
However, during the first cycle of cetuximab, she expe rienced a severe allergic reaction, presenting with facial 
erythema, coughing, and acute respiratory distress. 
Despite pre-treatment for the second cycle, she still con tinued to experience similar allergic symptoms.
Through the above treatment, the patient’s vaginal 
bleeding significantly improved, and the carcinoembry onic antigen (CEA) levels markedly decreased, indicating 
a high likelihood of the current treatment regimen being 
effective. However, the patient experienced severe hyper sensitivity reaction, grade 3. According to the guidelines, 
cetuximab should be discontinued or switched to a simi lar drug. Unfortunately, panitumumab is not available in 
China and also carries a risk of infusion reactions. Thus, 
there are no better or safer treatment options available 
for this patient.
On the basis of multiple literature reports [8 –10], the 
clinical team decided to use a dose escalation method 
for the third cycle (please refer to Table  1 for details). 
After obtaining specific informed consent from the 
patient, on 17 May 2024, the patient began weekly 
administration of 450  mg (250  mg/m2) of cetuximab, divided into three bags: bag 1: 9  mg (2%) in 250  ml 
saline, bag 2: 58.5 mg (13%) in 250 ml saline, and bag 3: 
382.5 mg (85%) in 250 ml saline. The dose was escalated 
in the following manner: 2  days prior and on the day 
of administration, the patient took oral acetaminophen 
300 mg and montelukast 10 mg once daily, as well as on 
the day of the procedure; 30 minutes before the infu sion, the patient received intravenous dexamethasone 
(15 mg) and chlorpheniramine (10 mg), in addition to 
intravenous cimetidine (0.3 g) and ondansetron (8 mg). 
Bag 1 infused at 80  ml per hour for 15  minutes, then 
increased to 120  ml per hour, 260  ml per hour, and 
540  ml per hour every 15  minutes if no adverse reac tions occurred. Bag 2 followed the same escalation as 
bag 1. Bag 3 infused at 80 ml per hour for 15 minutes, 
then increased to 115 ml per hour for 2 hours if toler ated. The infusion process was closely monitored with 
ECG  (Electrocardiograph) monitoring and emergency 
medications. The first two bags were infused without 
any adverse reactions. During the infusion of bag 3, the 
patient experienced mild coughing and focal wheezing, 
which was managed with salbutamol (5 mg) via oxygen 
nebulization and without stopping cetuximab infu sion. After stabilization, the infusion was completed 
successfully.
We repeated this protocol for the fourth and fifth 
cycles, taking 5 hours in total, with no significant adverse 
reactions other than transient hypertension, which 
relieved without intervention.

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Cetuximab, an important anti-EGFR monoclonal anti body, has shown significant efficacy in treating advanced 
colorectal cancer and other diseases. However, infusion 
reactions, particularly severe ones (up to 3%), greatly 
limit its clinical use [7]. We review relevant literature and 
introduces our optimized drug infusion protocol.
Initially, we reviewed several pertinent studies to 
inform our approach. Jerath et al. [10] pioneered a doseescalation protocol for advanced breast cancer, success fully administering the drug by dividing the dose into five 
bags with a tenfold concentration increase. Saif et al. [11] 
explored the use of cetuximab for patients with previous 
allergies to panitumumab, utilizing five different infusion 
rates to ensure safe administration. In contrast, Hong 
et al. [12] conducted a dose escalation using a single bag. 
Our primary reference was García-Menaya et al. [8], who 
described a ten-step infusion method. Building on their 
work, we further optimized the dosage to enhance safety 
and efficacy. All cases involved pre-treatment protocols 
to mitigate allergic reactions, resulting in either no aller gic responses or only mild ones.
In our case, the patient was an elderly individual with 
limited treatment options. For advanced colorectal can cer with a BRAFV600E mutation, the optimal therapy is 
a combination of BRAF V600E inhibitors and anti-EGFR 
therapy. While the patient initially benefited from this 
treatment, she subsequently experienced a severe allergic 
reaction (grade 3). Given that alternative medications are 
not available in China, drug desensitization was consid ered a viable option. Building on previous research, we 
adjusted the desensitization protocol to enhance its clini cal feasibility.
To ensure the safe use of cetuximab, we recommend a 
thorough assessment of the patient’s history of drug and 
food allergies, as well as any autoimmune diseases, before 
initiating treatment. In well-equipped centers, it is advis able to conduct pre-treatment drug skin tests [13] or 
measure specific immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels, such as 
those for galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose (alpha-Gal) [14]. 
If the skin test or IgE levels are positive, it strongly indi cates a high likelihood of an allergic reaction. For these 
high-risk patients requiring cetuximab, ensure thorough 
premedication or consider directly using a desensitiza tion protocol. Additionally, cetuximab should be admin istered in centers that have emergency equipment and 
experienced staff to ensure patient safety.
Conclusion
Successful administration of cetuximab using the dose 
escalation method provides valuable experience and ref erence for clinical practice. With further research and new technology applications, the clinical use of cetuxi mab will become safer and more effective.
